THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XVI, NO. 11.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 8, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HARLAN THE LIKELY COACH

TO DEBATE BIG COLLEGE

THE 'VARSITY TRACK TEAM

LACROSSE WORK STARTED

Salary Question the Only Bar—Alumni
to Meet and Discuss FourYear Rule.

Hopkins Will Meet College of City of
New York With Two Teams
in the Spring.

Outlook for Coming Season Encouraging.
Schedule Not Complete—Last
Year's Men Available.

Large Number of Candidates Practicing
Regularly in the Cage—Hard
Schedule Arranged.

The selection of Eddie Harlan as
coach of the football and baseball
teams of the University has practically been settled by the committee
in charge of the matter and the only
detail to be completed now is the
ratification of the committee's action
by the athletic board. The only
difficulty that has been encountered
is in regard to salary, but it is
believed that an agreement concerning this matter will be made.
Harlan is the only man that has
been considered for the position,
and should the athletic board allow
the financial question to interfere
With his selection as coach, the committee would have all of its work
to do over again, and a temporary
coach for the baseball team would
have to be selected at once.
The advisability of continuing the
Present athletic policy is being questioned by some of the alumni is indicated by the fact that a large
mass-meetinp- of the alumni has
been called, to be held at the Hopkins Club, January 23, to discuss
the whole football situation. A
communication was sent to every
alumni in this city to be present at
this meeting and each one was requested to present his views in
Written form. The letter follows:
BALTIMORE, Jan. 2, 1911.
DEAR SIR—The alumni athletic ad-

The University Debate Committee is completing arrangements for
what is in many ways the most ambitious debate a Hopkins team has
ever undertaken. After long negotiation with many institutions, the
committee picked out the College
of the City of New York as the
most desirable opponent for the
present year. It is possible that a
third college may be added to form
a triangular league similar to the
one that was arranged last year between Hopkins, Washington and
Lee, and Gettysburg; but in case
this is not found possible, a dual
system will probably be adopted,
by which a debate will be held on
the same evening at each institution. Each college will uphold
both sides of -the question.
The College of the City of New
York is a very large institution,
having at the last session an enrollment of over 3,700; and the reputation its students enjoy for scholarship and serious wcrk is widely
known. It is in many respects
similarly situated to Hopkins, and
enjoys access to the magnificent
libraries and institutions of New
York city. On all these accounts
it is expected to turn out two debating teams that will put up a hard
fight on any question. Previous to
this year it has been engaged in a
series of debates with Tufts College.
The question for debate and the
date of the contest have not been
settled as yet, but preliminary work
toward making these arrangements
is,in progress. Whatever the squestion may be, the fact that each institution will have to put out a team
to represent both sides will do
away with any advantage to either.
The certainty of a trip to New
York for the members of one team
ought to encourage active competition for places in the contest. The
best possible preparation and the
most aggressive efforts will be
called forth by the calibre of Hopkins' opponent.
The Debating Committee for the
present year is composed of Messrs.
T. B. Price, '12, chairman; L.
Rogers.'12; W: 0. WeyfOrth, '12;
A. E. Sattler and C. L. Getz, 'i3;
and S. D. White, '14. Mr. Getz
was unanimously elected manager
of the debate at a recent meeting
of the committee,

The organization meeting for
the 'Varsity track team was held
in the Trophy Room, on Thursday.
Captain Lee opened the meeting
with a brief speech and introduced
Joseph T. England to the new men.
England explained the serious
proposition the team has this year,
and that it has to depend upon a
gredt number of new men. The
squad of freshmen was encouraging.
The next speaker was Coach
Kocher. He told how the choice of
track athletics, for a student, was
such that he could study all the
time he needed, and could use the
short time of practice for his daily
exercise. The exercise is moderate
and does not completely tire out
the man.
The following schedule, not yet
complete, was announced by W. N.
Brown, the manager.
February io—The George Washington games are scheduled at
Washington. This meet will serve
as a great help to the men who
enter the contests at the Hopkins
meet the next Saturday.
February 7—All candidates for
the team will get their try-out in
this meet.
March 2 is the date for the annual Georgetown games at Washington.
A month and a half then elapses
before the outdoor season begins.
Hopkins meets Swarthmore for the
first time on the track, April 20,
at Homewood. The next week the
relay team goes to Philadelphia for
the Pennsylvania Relay Carnival.
The dates for the Navy and
Virginia meets have not been finally settled.
The first meet of the South Atlantic Intercollegiate A. IA., which
has been formed to include North
Carolina, Georgetown and Hopkins,
will be held at Homewood after
the dual meets are over. This meet
will be the biggest affair for the
'Varsity team..
The following men of last year's
team are eligible again this year,
and should form a basis to which
the great number of freshmen can
be added:

Organized practice of the lacrosse candidates began during the
Christmas holidays in the cage.
The large number of candidates
made it necessary to divide the
squad into two sections, one of
which practices on Mondays and
Wednesdays, and the other on
Tuesdays and Fridays. These sections will practice separately in the
cage until the weather permits
practice at Homewood.
Manager John K. Burgan received last week the schedule of
games for the Southern division of
the Intercollegiate Lacrosse League
which was arranged by the Executive Committee of the League.
Until last year the championship
games were arranged by the managers of the respective teams, but
such difficulty was experienced as
to whether the games should be
played late or early in the season
that the Executive Committee was
appealed to. The schedule they arranged will hold good for a number
of years. A system of rotation
provides that the team which plays
the last game this year with Hopkins will play the first game here
next year, and so on. Hopkins and
Lehigh played the final contest last
year, and this year they will be
the first to oppose. The championship of the Southern section of the
Intercollegiate Lacrosse League will
be settled by the result of the following three games:
Saturday, April 27—Hopkins vs.
Lehigh, at South Bethlehem, Pa.;
Stevens vs. Swarthmore, at Swarthmore, Pa.
Saturday, May 4—Hopkins vs.
Swarthmore, at Homewood ; Stevens vs. Lehigh, at South Bethlehem, Pa.
Saturday, May i I—Hopkins vs.
Stevens, at Hoboken, N. J.; Lehigh vs. Swarthmore, at Swarthmore, pa.
Additional (Tames are as.follows
Saturday,'
'March 30—Hopkins
vs. Hopkins Alumni, at Homewood.
Saturday, April 6—Hopkins VS:
Cornell, at Homewood.
Saturday, April 13—Hopkins VS.
Harvard, at Homewood.
Saturday, April 20—Hopkins vs.
Carlisle, at Homewood.
These latter games will be played
before the League games and will
give Hopkins good practice. before
they go out for the championship.
and the coaches will have ample
time to note and correct the defect
of the klopkins team.

Yisers hereby call a meeting of those
interested in the future welfare of football at Johns Hopkins University to discuss the difficulties which have confronted us this year and to consider the
est policies to pursue in the future.
his meeting will be for discussion only,
no vote will be taken. You are requested
to formulate your views as concisely as
Possible, and, if possible, bring them in
Written form, so as not to consume any
unnecessary time.
The meeting will be held in the Johns
Iiopkins Club, Tuesday, January 23, at
M. Please be present, if possible.
v ,s-rY truly yours, H. B. Stone, T. E.
Strdus, G. A. Stewart, R. B. Roulston,
A. Dobbin,
W. C. Schmeisser,
G. P. Raleigh Jr.,
and Horace Burrough
(chairman), board of advisers.

The selection of Eddie Harlan as
football and baseball coach will not
be discussed at the meeting as the
committee has already decided that
he is the man that they want, and the
.
(3nly thing that remains to be done
Is for the athletic board to give its
sanction to the committee's action.
Harlan is considered one of the
best football coaches in the country.
While at Princeton lie played in .thc
backfield,.and was one of the most
brilliant performers that has ever
Played football at that institution.

Freshmen Elect Track Captain.

Saturday Morning Lectures Begun.

On Saturday morning a course of
public lectures was begun on "Backward and Feeble-Minded Children
and Related Phases of Clinical Psvcholog-y." The lectures ‘vill be
given from eleven to twelve o'clock
every Saturday until the end of
the Lniversity year.
The object of the course is, first,
to present some representative work
that is being done in the study and
treatment of defective children ;
econd, to make as intelligible as
possible certain psychological conceptions which are currently used
in the study of cases.
The course has reference, on one
hand, to the needs of soc:al workers, physicians; teachers and others
who have to do with defectives ;
on the other hand, to the morz
theoretical interest in these problems by students of psychology,
sociology and education. There
will be opportunity for questions
and such discussion as time may
permit.
Dr. Edmund B. Huey, who has
recently been appointed lecturer on
mental development in the University and assistant in the Phipps
clinic of the Hospital, will deliver
the lectures.

track meeting, partly for other reasons, the reorganization was postponed until next Tuesday. Two
temporary teams were then chosen,

former team won by the score of
22 to 9. The game was marked
by the brilliant playing of Captain
Price, who was formerly a star at
Davidson College.

During the Christmas holidays
the University Musical clubs took
a three days' trip on the Eastern
Shore of Maryland, to the towns
of Chestertown, Easton and Salisbury. Although the audiences were
not large, owing to the bad weather which was experienced, the clubs
were most cordially received in
every one of the towns. At Chestertown and at Salisbury, the members were invited to tea in the afternoon, while at all three places a
dance was held after the concert.
The Musical clubs left Baltimore on Tuesday morning, December 26, and arrived in Chestertown late that afternoon. The
next day the trip was made to
Easton, and on Thursday Salisbury
was reached. On Friday morning
t he return trip was made through
C:a:bourne on the Steamer Cambridge to Baltimore.
Although hardly a financial success, the trip was most successful
as far as enjoyment was concerned,
and it was a poor, but most enthusiastic, crowd which gathered on
the returning steamer to give an
impromptu concert as a sort of
aftermath.
Those who made the rtip were:
Mr J. S. Fulton, leader of the Glee
Club; Mr. W. Ray, leader of the •
Instrumental Club; Mr. Taylor
Stark, accompanist, and Messrs.
Weyforth, Mason, Everton, Wagner, Galloway, Warner, Niles, Uhler. Hinrichs, Howell, Barton, Tappan, Schmied, Geissel, Lloyd, Weber, Jacobs, Corner, Belt, Leland
and Gillet.
Manager Leland has already
made arrangements for concerts to
le held in Baltimore later this
month. The most important of
these will be "The' 'concert, which
is to be held in McCoy Hall on the
evening of Saturday, January 27.
Following the concert there will be
a dance, and if this concert comes
up to the standard set last rear, it
will be a great success. One week
before the McCoy Hall concert the
Musical clubs will give a concert
at St. Michaels and All Angels'
Church of this city.

The annual joint meeting of the
Archaeological Institute of America and the American Philological
Association was held at Pittsburgh
on December 27, 28 and 29, 1911.
Among those who attended from
Baltimore were Professors C. W.E.
Miller, W. P. Mustard, D. M.
Robinson, Kirby Flower Smith,
and H. L. Wilson, of the Johns
Hopkins University. Papers were
Presented by Professors Wilson
and Miller, and the response .to the
address of welcome was made by
Professor Smith. At • the meeting
of the Council, which is the governingbody of the Archaeological
Institute, Professor Wilson was
elected vice-president and requested
tQ take charge of all matters relating to the excavat:ons and foreign
relations of the Institute.

The annual dinner of the Class
of 1902 was held on Tuesday evening, December 26, at the University Club. It was generally admitted to be the best and most
enthusiastic dinner thus far held.
The theme of most of those who
spoke was in connection with the
advancement of the University
along different lines, especially athletic. Incidentally, in these talks,
the important work that is being
done in various parts of the country by members of the Class should
make '02 feel proud of her record.
Much interest was displayed in the
decennial celebration of the Class
in 1912, and a unique program is
to be planned by a special committee composed of Messrs. Marburv,
Pearre and Wolman in co-operation with the secretary, R. C.
Sharretts.

5 P. M.-Introductory Lecture of the
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.:
I am not a chronic kicker and this is
the first time that I have rushed into
Print with my grievances, but I feel that
Possibly .my case is typical and that,
therefore, in registering a protest, I•may
be rendering a service to my fellow-sufferers.
No less than three times since the
opening of the University have I found
hairpins in books in the main library.
One book I was taking home, and while
reading it in the car I noticed across the
aisle two girls giggling. When I investigated I found that one of these ordinary, garden variety of hair retainers
was serving as a book mark.
I don't mind finding stray strands of
hair, the elusive scent of cologne,. or
traces of powder between the leaves of
books, but I do object to our fair co-eds
using hairpins as markers and forgetting
to remove them. SUEFERING STUDENT.

"Suffering Student" overlooks
the fact that there is a silver lining to every cloud. The hairpin
performs many useful functions,
and in the hands. of one entirely
great, is mightier than the sword.
It can be used to reduce the asthma
of clogged tobacco pipes, and,many
a student often 'wishes for one
When his brier or meerschaum refuses to work properly and he has
to bum a coffin nail from one of
his friends. This merit alone would
exculpate the fair co-eds from the•
Stigma which has been placed upon
them.
In skilled hands, a hairpin has
also been used, according to competent authorities, to pick a lock,
Pull a cork, peel an apple, fasten a
door, pull a nail, take the cotton out
of a•boarding-house gas jet, clean a
lamp chimney, clean a watch, pry
refractory studs into .the diminutive buttonholes of a boiled shirt,
mend a pair of trousers, untie a
knot, button gloves, doctor an automobile, cut a piece of pie, clean
finger nails, take the crown off a
beer bottle, button shoes, cut the
Pages of a book, make a fishhook,
take the shell out of a gun ; in
fact, nearly everything but remove
Whiskers. "Suffering Student" has
Probably no occasion to regret the
hairpin's inadequacy in the tonsorial line, or he wouldn't have written
this letter.
Mayor Baker Here.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY
FOOTBALL PLAYERS HONORED

CHESS PLAYERS .ACTIVE

7

8, 1912.

A BUSINESS SCHOOL
Of Exceptional Merit

Letters Presented to Squad at Annual
Blow-Out—Ellicott Manager
for Next Year.

At the annual football blow-out,
Which was held in the cage Thursday night, December 21, Mr. J.
Pembroke Thom presented the
football squad and the manager
With the letters which had been
awarded at the last meeting of the
Board .of Directors of the Hopkins
General Athletic Association.
Eighteen players received the
much-coveted "H." They were
Captain Fulton, Gillet, Lichensperger, Gittings, Belt, Melamet,
.Morton Rohde, Davis, Duffy, Dorsey, Bridgman, Catlin, Stollenwerck, Branham, Pieper, Dodson,
and Musser.
Ellicott, Hopkins, Chenoweth,
LaMotte, Brady and Nagle received the "H. A. A." Manager
Getz was given an "H. M." and
the Athletic Board also gave him
a vote of thanks for his efficient
services during the past season.
Special mention was made of Barton, Yost and Randall, who, altliQugh they did not play in any
of the 'Varsity games, nevertheless faithfully attended all the
practices.
Much enthusiasm was shown by
all who attended the blow-out, and
a number of speeches were Made.
The speakers were Messrs. J. Morfut Muller, Joseph T. England, J.
Pembroke Thom, Dr. Harvey B.
Stone, George M. Gillet, Jr.; C.
Leland Getz, J. W. Davis, C. Ellis
Ellicott, and Richard S. McCabe.
John S. Fulton, Jr., the president
of the Athletic Association presided.
C. Ellis Ellicott, Jr., was elected
manager of the football team for
next season, at the last meeting of
the Athletic Board. He has been
a member of the football squad for
three years and is well acquainted
With many of the problems connected with the management.
Dr. Harvey B. Stone was elected
to succeed Mr. J. Pembroke Thom,
Who resigned as football adviser.
Dr. Stone and Mr. Horace Burroughs will be the advisers for
next year. Dr. Robert B. Roulgton
and Mr. Robert Dobbin, Jr., were
chosen as advisers for the baseball
team.
Although no games have been
scheduled as yet for the 1912 football season, Manager Ellicott has
received a, number of offers of
games. Among the teams which
are anxious to play Hopkins are
Lehigh, Swarthmore, Rutgers,
Stevens, Georgetown, Delaware
College, Ursinus, Haverford, Randolph-Macon and the Pennsylvania
Military Academy. Virginia, Gettysburg and the Carlisle Indians,
as well as the various Maryland
teams, will have to be 'considered
in making out the schedule.

Several Dual Matches Are
Contemplated.

Though not quite so much interest in chess has been shown this
year as made last year such a banner one for the royal game, the
boards in Levering Hall have been
in demand, and the Chess Club has
decided to provide several more
sets so that there need never be
any trouble in getting hold of one.
The *regular major and minor tournaments will be started in a few
days.
Last year the tournaments were
held late in the year, and many
who were just learning the game
were thus handicapped. Interclass matches will be played and
plans are under way for a match
with the University of Pennsylvania, and for correspondence
matches with several of the other
big colleges. The dues of the
Chess Club have been changed
this year from one dollar to fifty
cents.
The Club is generous enough to
provide boards and men for all,
and those who use them should be
fair enough to join. The membership is open to everyone and both
graduate and undergraduate will
be gladly welcomed. If you don't
know how to play you should learn,
and any member will be only too
glad to teach you.
The officers of the Club are:
President, W. E. Pearce, Jr.; vicepresident, Bertram Benedict; secretary-treasurer, A. L. Hammond.

Freshmen Gymnastic Contests.

The, opposing teams for the
annual freshman indoor gymnastic
contests were picked last Friday
afternoon at a meeting of the captains and Mr. Theodore Kistler in
the trophy room. The teams are
called the Greens and the Whites,
after the freshman class colors.
Stephen J. Thompson is captain
of the Greens and his assistants are
Millard Eisenman and Joel H.
Swartz. The others on the team
are: Mason, Deems, Dewitt, Tarr,
short, Hinricks, Weech, Levy, Sun,
Barroway, Brooke, Prince, Ebaugh,
and Warren.
The Whites are captained by
Allen F. Voshell who is assisted by
J. G. D. Hutzler and Thomas H.
Troxell. The rest of the team includes Bennett, Lederer, Baker, Lieberknecht, Spencer, Scharf, Sachs,
Hall, Hummel, Thomas, Stewart,
Biser, Uhler and Schloss.
A series of twenty contests will
be held, and the member of the
winning team will be awarded
medals. Three individual prizes
will be awarded to the highest point
winners, irrespective of their sides.

Literary Society Meets.

At the last meeting of the
Arbitration-Literary Society before
Christmas the following officers and
committees were elected to hold
office until Easter: President, J. E.
Uhler; Vice-President, A. Wolman ;
Secretary, G. Y. Rusk; Treasurer,
A. L. Hammond; Librarian, D. N.
Shulman. Program Committee:
Schmied, White, Uhler. Membership Committee: Price Barroway,
Brodie.
At the meeting last Thursday
committees were appointed to arrange for the Freshman Peace Contest, for a debate with the Literary
Society of the University of Pennsylvania, and for the Maryland
Peace Prize. The sense of the
meeting was that everyone who intends to compete in these contests
should join the society at once.
Hammond, Brodie, Schmied and
White were appointed to take part
on the literary program next week.

Elected President.

Dr. Hugh H. Young, associate
professor of genito-urinary surgery
in the Johns Hopkins Medical
School, was inaugurated as president of the Medical and Chirurgical
'Faculty of Maryland at a smoker
held at its building Friday night.
During Dr. Young's speech he referred to Dr. William H. Welch
as "the foremost citizen of the
United States, in the eyes of the
medical profession."
"What did your mother-in-law
give you for your birthday?"
"A motto, reading: 'I will be with
you all days, even unto the end of
the world.'"—Satire.

Dr. Nitobe to Lecture.

Dr. Inazo Nitobe, president of
the First National College and professor in the Imperial University
of Tokio, will give a series of
lectures on "Some Characteristics
of the Land and People of Japan."
Dr. Nitobe's lectures will be given
in McCoy Hall at five o'clock and
will be open to the public.
Thursday, January i i — Introductory.
Monday,January 15—Geographical Features of Japan.
Thursday, January IS—History.
Monday, January 22—Race and
Racial Traits.
Thursday, January 25—Religion.
Monday, January 29— Moral
Ideals and Morals.
Thursday, February 1—Industrial Problems.
Monday, February 5—Relations
Between Japan and America.
Dr. Nitobe was for three years
a student at Hopkins, and took a
doctor of philosophy degree in
Germany. He is also advisor to
the government of Formosa, and
has written numerous books of
social and economic importance.

HARLAN THE LIKELY COACH

TO DEBATE BIG COLLEGE

THE 'VARSITY TRACK TEAM

LACROSSE WORK STARTED

Salary Question the Only Bar—Alumni
to Meet and Discuss FourYear Rule.

Hopkins Will Meet College of City of
New York With Two Teams
in the Spring.

Outlook for Coming Season Encouraging.
Schedule Not Complete—Last
Year's Men Available.

Large Number of Candidates Practicing
Regularly in the Cage—Hard
Schedule Arranged.

The selection of Eddie Harlan as
coach of the football and baseball
teams of the University has practically been settled by the committee
in charge of the matter and the only
detail to be completed now is the
ratification of the committee's action
by the athletic board. The only
difficulty that has been encountered
is in regard to salary, but it is
believed that an agreement concerning this matter will be made.
Harlan is the only man that has
been considered for the position,
and should the athletic board allow
the financial question to interfere
With his selection as coach, the committee would have all of its work
to do over again, and a temporary
coach for the baseball team would
have to be selected at once.
The advisability of continuing the
Present athletic policy is being questioned by some of the alumni is indicated by the fact that a large
mass-meetinp- of the alumni has
been called, to be held at the Hopkins Club, January 23, to discuss
the whole football situation. A
communication was sent to every
alumni in this city to be present at
this meeting and each one was requested to present his views in
Written form. The letter follows:
BALTIMORE, Jan. 2, 1911.
DEAR SIR—The alumni athletic ad-

The University Debate Committee is completing arrangements for
what is in many ways the most ambitious debate a Hopkins team has
ever undertaken. After long negotiation with many institutions, the
committee picked out the College
of the City of New York as the
most desirable opponent for the
present year. It is possible that a
third college may be added to form
a triangular league similar to the
one that was arranged last year between Hopkins, Washington and
Lee, and Gettysburg; but in case
this is not found possible, a dual
system will probably be adopted,
by which a debate will be held on
the same evening at each institution. Each college will uphold
both sides of -the question.
The College of the City of New
York is a very large institution,
having at the last session an enrollment of over 3,700; and the reputation its students enjoy for scholarship and serious wcrk is widely
known. It is in many respects
similarly situated to Hopkins, and
enjoys access to the magnificent
libraries and institutions of New
York city. On all these accounts
it is expected to turn out two debating teams that will put up a hard
fight on any question. Previous to
this year it has been engaged in a
series of debates with Tufts College.
The question for debate and the
date of the contest have not been
settled as yet, but preliminary work
toward making these arrangements
is,in progress. Whatever the squestion may be, the fact that each institution will have to put out a team
to represent both sides will do
away with any advantage to either.
The certainty of a trip to New
York for the members of one team
ought to encourage active competition for places in the contest. The
best possible preparation and the
most aggressive efforts will be
called forth by the calibre of Hopkins' opponent.
The Debating Committee for the
present year is composed of Messrs.
T. B. Price, '12, chairman; L.
Rogers.'12; W: 0. WeyfOrth, '12;
A. E. Sattler and C. L. Getz, 'i3;
and S. D. White, '14. Mr. Getz
was unanimously elected manager
of the debate at a recent meeting
of the committee,

The organization meeting for
the 'Varsity track team was held
in the Trophy Room, on Thursday.
Captain Lee opened the meeting
with a brief speech and introduced
Joseph T. England to the new men.
England explained the serious
proposition the team has this year,
and that it has to depend upon a
gredt number of new men. The
squad of freshmen was encouraging.
The next speaker was Coach
Kocher. He told how the choice of
track athletics, for a student, was
such that he could study all the
time he needed, and could use the
short time of practice for his daily
exercise. The exercise is moderate
and does not completely tire out
the man.
The following schedule, not yet
complete, was announced by W. N.
Brown, the manager.
February io—The George Washington games are scheduled at
Washington. This meet will serve
as a great help to the men who
enter the contests at the Hopkins
meet the next Saturday.
February 7—All candidates for
the team will get their try-out in
this meet.
March 2 is the date for the annual Georgetown games at Washington.
A month and a half then elapses
before the outdoor season begins.
Hopkins meets Swarthmore for the
first time on the track, April 20,
at Homewood. The next week the
relay team goes to Philadelphia for
the Pennsylvania Relay Carnival.
The dates for the Navy and
Virginia meets have not been finally settled.
The first meet of the South Atlantic Intercollegiate A. IA., which
has been formed to include North
Carolina, Georgetown and Hopkins,
will be held at Homewood after
the dual meets are over. This meet
will be the biggest affair for the
'Varsity team..
The following men of last year's
team are eligible again this year,
and should form a basis to which
the great number of freshmen can
be added:

Organized practice of the lacrosse candidates began during the
Christmas holidays in the cage.
The large number of candidates
made it necessary to divide the
squad into two sections, one of
which practices on Mondays and
Wednesdays, and the other on
Tuesdays and Fridays. These sections will practice separately in the
cage until the weather permits
practice at Homewood.
Manager John K. Burgan received last week the schedule of
games for the Southern division of
the Intercollegiate Lacrosse League
which was arranged by the Executive Committee of the League.
Until last year the championship
games were arranged by the managers of the respective teams, but
such difficulty was experienced as
to whether the games should be
played late or early in the season
that the Executive Committee was
appealed to. The schedule they arranged will hold good for a number
of years. A system of rotation
provides that the team which plays
the last game this year with Hopkins will play the first game here
next year, and so on. Hopkins and
Lehigh played the final contest last
year, and this year they will be
the first to oppose. The championship of the Southern section of the
Intercollegiate Lacrosse League will
be settled by the result of the following three games:
Saturday, April 27—Hopkins vs.
Lehigh, at South Bethlehem, Pa.;
Stevens vs. Swarthmore, at Swarthmore, Pa.
Saturday, May 4—Hopkins vs.
Swarthmore, at Homewood ; Stevens vs. Lehigh, at South Bethlehem, Pa.
Saturday, May i I—Hopkins vs.
Stevens, at Hoboken, N. J.; Lehigh vs. Swarthmore, at Swarthmore, pa.
Additional (Tames are as.follows
Saturday,'
'March 30—Hopkins
vs. Hopkins Alumni, at Homewood.
Saturday, April 6—Hopkins VS:
Cornell, at Homewood.
Saturday, April 13—Hopkins VS.
Harvard, at Homewood.
Saturday, April 20—Hopkins vs.
Carlisle, at Homewood.
These latter games will be played
before the League games and will
give Hopkins good practice. before
they go out for the championship.
and the coaches will have ample
time to note and correct the defect
of the klopkins team.

Saturday Morning Lectures Begun.

On Saturday morning a course of
public lectures was begun on "Backward and Feeble-Minded Children
and Related Phases of Clinical Psvcholog-y." The lectures ‘vill be
given from eleven to twelve o'clock
every Saturday until the end of
the Lniversity year.
The object of the course is, first,
to present some representative work
that is being done in the study and
treatment of defective children ;
econd, to make as intelligible as
possible certain psychological conceptions which are currently used
in the study of cases.
The course has reference, on one
hand, to the needs of soc:al workers, physicians; teachers and others
who have to do with defectives ;
on the other hand, to the morz
theoretical interest in these problems by students of psychology,
sociology and education. There
will be opportunity for questions
and such discussion as time may
permit.
Dr. Edmund B. Huey, who has
recently been appointed lecturer on
mental development in the University and assistant in the Phipps
clinic of the Hospital, will deliver
the lectures.

During the Christmas holidays
the University Musical clubs took
a three days' trip on the Eastern
Shore of Maryland, to the towns
of Chestertown, Easton and Salisbury. Although the audiences were
not large, owing to the bad weather which was experienced, the clubs
were most cordially received in
every one of the towns. At Chestertown and at Salisbury, the members were invited to tea in the afternoon, while at all three places a
dance was held after the concert.
The Musical clubs left Baltimore on Tuesday morning, December 26, and arrived in Chestertown late that afternoon. The
next day the trip was made to
Easton, and on Thursday Salisbury
was reached. On Friday morning
t he return trip was made through
C:a:bourne on the Steamer Cambridge to Baltimore.
Although hardly a financial success, the trip was most successful
as far as enjoyment was concerned,
and it was a poor, but most enthusiastic, crowd which gathered on
the returning steamer to give an
impromptu concert as a sort of
aftermath.
Those who made the rtip were:
Mr J. S. Fulton, leader of the Glee
Club; Mr. W. Ray, leader of the •
Instrumental Club; Mr. Taylor
Stark, accompanist, and Messrs.
Weyforth, Mason, Everton, Wagner, Galloway, Warner, Niles, Uhler. Hinrichs, Howell, Barton, Tappan, Schmied, Geissel, Lloyd, Weber, Jacobs, Corner, Belt, Leland
and Gillet.
Manager Leland has already
made arrangements for concerts to
le held in Baltimore later this
month. The most important of
these will be "The' 'concert, which
is to be held in McCoy Hall on the
evening of Saturday, January 27.
Following the concert there will be
a dance, and if this concert comes
up to the standard set last rear, it
will be a great success. One week
before the McCoy Hall concert the
Musical clubs will give a concert
at St. Michaels and All Angels'
Church of this city.

The annual joint meeting of the
Archaeological Institute of America and the American Philological
Association was held at Pittsburgh
on December 27, 28 and 29, 1911.
Among those who attended from
Baltimore were Professors C. W.E.
Miller, W. P. Mustard, D. M.
Robinson, Kirby Flower Smith,
and H. L. Wilson, of the Johns
Hopkins University. Papers were
Presented by Professors Wilson
and Miller, and the response .to the
address of welcome was made by
Professor Smith. At • the meeting
of the Council, which is the governingbody of the Archaeological
Institute, Professor Wilson was
elected vice-president and requested
tQ take charge of all matters relating to the excavat:ons and foreign
relations of the Institute.

The annual dinner of the Class
of 1902 was held on Tuesday evening, December 26, at the University Club. It was generally admitted to be the best and most
enthusiastic dinner thus far held.
The theme of most of those who
spoke was in connection with the
advancement of the University
along different lines, especially athletic. Incidentally, in these talks,
the important work that is being
done in various parts of the country by members of the Class should
make '02 feel proud of her record.
Much interest was displayed in the
decennial celebration of the Class
in 1912, and a unique program is
to be planned by a special committee composed of Messrs. Marburv,
Pearre and Wolman in co-operation with the secretary, R. C.
Sharretts.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.:
I am not a chronic kicker and this is
the first time that I have rushed into
Print with my grievances, but I feel that
Possibly .my case is typical and that,
therefore, in registering a protest, I•may
be rendering a service to my fellow-sufferers.
No less than three times since the
opening of the University have I found
hairpins in books in the main library.
One book I was taking home, and while
reading it in the car I noticed across the
aisle two girls giggling. When I investigated I found that one of these ordinary, garden variety of hair retainers
was serving as a book mark.
I don't mind finding stray strands of
hair, the elusive scent of cologne,. or
traces of powder between the leaves of
books, but I do object to our fair co-eds
using hairpins as markers and forgetting
to remove them. SUEFERING STUDENT.

"Suffering Student" overlooks
the fact that there is a silver lining to every cloud. The hairpin
performs many useful functions,
and in the hands. of one entirely
great, is mightier than the sword.
It can be used to reduce the asthma
of clogged tobacco pipes, and,many
a student often 'wishes for one
When his brier or meerschaum refuses to work properly and he has
to bum a coffin nail from one of
his friends. This merit alone would
exculpate the fair co-eds from the•
Stigma which has been placed upon
them.
In skilled hands, a hairpin has
also been used, according to competent authorities, to pick a lock,
Pull a cork, peel an apple, fasten a
door, pull a nail, take the cotton out
of a•boarding-house gas jet, clean a
lamp chimney, clean a watch, pry
refractory studs into .the diminutive buttonholes of a boiled shirt,
mend a pair of trousers, untie a
knot, button gloves, doctor an automobile, cut a piece of pie, clean
finger nails, take the crown off a
beer bottle, button shoes, cut the
Pages of a book, make a fishhook,
take the shell out of a gun ; in
fact, nearly everything but remove
Whiskers. "Suffering Student" has
Probably no occasion to regret the
hairpin's inadequacy in the tonsorial line, or he wouldn't have written
this letter.

FOOTBALL PLAYERS HONORED

8, 1912.

A BUSINESS SCHOOL
Of Exceptional Merit

Letters Presented to Squad at Annual
Blow-Out—Ellicott Manager
for Next Year.

At the annual football blow-out,
Which was held in the cage Thursday night, December 21, Mr. J.
Pembroke Thom presented the
football squad and the manager
With the letters which had been
awarded at the last meeting of the
Board .of Directors of the Hopkins
General Athletic Association.
Eighteen players received the
much-coveted "H." They were
Captain Fulton, Gillet, Lichensperger, Gittings, Belt, Melamet,
.Morton Rohde, Davis, Duffy, Dorsey, Bridgman, Catlin, Stollenwerck, Branham, Pieper, Dodson,
and Musser.
Ellicott, Hopkins, Chenoweth,
LaMotte, Brady and Nagle received the "H. A. A." Manager
Getz was given an "H. M." and
the Athletic Board also gave him
a vote of thanks for his efficient
services during the past season.
Special mention was made of Barton, Yost and Randall, who, altliQugh they did not play in any
of the 'Varsity games, nevertheless faithfully attended all the
practices.
Much enthusiasm was shown by
all who attended the blow-out, and
a number of speeches were Made.
The speakers were Messrs. J. Morfut Muller, Joseph T. England, J.
Pembroke Thom, Dr. Harvey B.
Stone, George M. Gillet, Jr.; C.
Leland Getz, J. W. Davis, C. Ellis
Ellicott, and Richard S. McCabe.
John S. Fulton, Jr., the president
of the Athletic Association presided.
C. Ellis Ellicott, Jr., was elected
manager of the football team for
next season, at the last meeting of
the Athletic Board. He has been
a member of the football squad for
three years and is well acquainted
With many of the problems connected with the management.
Dr. Harvey B. Stone was elected
to succeed Mr. J. Pembroke Thom,
Who resigned as football adviser.
Dr. Stone and Mr. Horace Burroughs will be the advisers for
next year. Dr. Robert B. Roulgton
and Mr. Robert Dobbin, Jr., were
chosen as advisers for the baseball
team.
Although no games have been
scheduled as yet for the 1912 football season, Manager Ellicott has
received a, number of offers of
games. Among the teams which
are anxious to play Hopkins are
Lehigh, Swarthmore, Rutgers,
Stevens, Georgetown, Delaware
College, Ursinus, Haverford, Randolph-Macon and the Pennsylvania
Military Academy. Virginia, Gettysburg and the Carlisle Indians,
as well as the various Maryland
teams, will have to be 'considered
in making out the schedule.

Though not quite so much interest in chess has been shown this
year as made last year such a banner one for the royal game, the
boards in Levering Hall have been
in demand, and the Chess Club has
decided to provide several more
sets so that there need never be
any trouble in getting hold of one.
The *regular major and minor tournaments will be started in a few
days.
Last year the tournaments were
held late in the year, and many
who were just learning the game
were thus handicapped. Interclass matches will be played and
plans are under way for a match
with the University of Pennsylvania, and for correspondence
matches with several of the other
big colleges. The dues of the
Chess Club have been changed
this year from one dollar to fifty
cents.
The Club is generous enough to
provide boards and men for all,
and those who use them should be
fair enough to join. The membership is open to everyone and both
graduate and undergraduate will
be gladly welcomed. If you don't
know how to play you should learn,
and any member will be only too
glad to teach you.
The officers of the Club are:
President, W. E. Pearce, Jr.; vicepresident, Bertram Benedict; secretary-treasurer, A. L. Hammond.

Freshmen Gymnastic Contests.

The, opposing teams for the
annual freshman indoor gymnastic
contests were picked last Friday
afternoon at a meeting of the captains and Mr. Theodore Kistler in
the trophy room. The teams are
called the Greens and the Whites,
after the freshman class colors.
Stephen J. Thompson is captain
of the Greens and his assistants are
Millard Eisenman and Joel H.
Swartz. The others on the team
are: Mason, Deems, Dewitt, Tarr,
short, Hinricks, Weech, Levy, Sun,
Barroway, Brooke, Prince, Ebaugh,
and Warren.
The Whites are captained by
Allen F. Voshell who is assisted by
J. G. D. Hutzler and Thomas H.
Troxell. The rest of the team includes Bennett, Lederer, Baker, Lieberknecht, Spencer, Scharf, Sachs,
Hall, Hummel, Thomas, Stewart,
Biser, Uhler and Schloss.
A series of twenty contests will
be held, and the member of the
winning team will be awarded
medals. Three individual prizes
will be awarded to the highest point
winners, irrespective of their sides.

University Directory

Literary Society Meets.

At the last meeting of the
Arbitration-Literary Society before
Christmas the following officers and
committees were elected to hold
office until Easter: President, J. E.
Uhler; Vice-President, A. Wolman ;
Secretary, G. Y. Rusk; Treasurer,
A. L. Hammond; Librarian, D. N.
Shulman. Program Committee:
Schmied, White, Uhler. Membership Committee: Price Barroway,
Brodie.
At the meeting last Thursday
committees were appointed to arrange for the Freshman Peace Contest, for a debate with the Literary
Society of the University of Pennsylvania, and for the Maryland
Peace Prize. The sense of the
meeting was that everyone who intends to compete in these contests
should join the society at once.
Hammond, Brodie, Schmied and
White were appointed to take part
on the literary program next week.
This Modest Freshman Should Attend
a Girls' School or Kindergarten.

Elected President.

Dr. Hugh H. Young, associate
professor of genito-urinary surgery
in the Johns Hopkins Medical
School, was inaugurated as president of the Medical and Chirurgical
'Faculty of Maryland at a smoker
held at its building Friday night.
During Dr. Young's speech he referred to Dr. William H. Welch
as "the foremost citizen of the
United States, in the eyes of the
medical profession."
"What did your mother-in-law
give you for your birthday?"
"A motto, reading: 'I will be with
you all days, even unto the end of
the world.'"—Satire.

It is very probable that the winners of the Southern division will
capture 'the championship of the
combined sections, because they
have done this for the past five
years, and no radical changes have
been notcd in the teams for the
coming season. The Swarthmore
game will be played in Baltimore
this year.

are bringing the candidates into
good shape rapidly, and when they
get out to Homewood in the spring

Dr. Nitobe to Lecture.

Dr. Inazo Nitobe, president of
the First National College and professor in the Imperial University
of Tokio, will give a series of
lectures on "Some Characteristics
of the Land and People of Japan."
Dr. Nitobe's lectures will be given
in McCoy Hall at five o'clock and
will be open to the public.
Thursday, January i i — Introductory.
Monday,January 15—Geographical Features of Japan.
Thursday, January IS—History.
Monday, January 22—Race and
Racial Traits.
Thursday, January 25—Religion.
Monday, January 29— Moral
Ideals and Morals.
Thursday, February 1—Industrial Problems.
Monday, February 5—Relations
Between Japan and America.
Dr. Nitobe was for three years
a student at Hopkins, and took a
doctor of philosophy degree in
Germany. He is also advisor to
the government of Formosa, and
has written numerous books of
social and economic importance.
